I will extract key points from this source.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nThis source discusses the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy. It mentions that Metformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. The review suggests that before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging, a more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed.\n```"

However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. I will extract key points from this source.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nThis source discusses the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy. It mentions that Metformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. The review suggests that before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging, a more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed.\n```"

I will extract key points from this source.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nThis source discusses the clinical applications of metformin in the prevention and treatment of aging and aging-related diseases. It highlights the role of metformin in targeting the hallmarks of aging, such as dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. Metformin has been shown to delay aging and display protective effects against aging-related diseases by modulating these hallmarks.\n```"

It is suggested that Metformin can slow aging, mitigate age-related diseases, extend lifespan, and increase health span. The drug is considered safe and has a good safety profile, with generally mild side effects such as gastrointestinal upset and vitamin B-12 deficiency. However, it is important to note that Metformin is not currently approved as an anti-aging treatment, and it is recommended to consult with a healthcare provider about the risks and potential benefits before considering its use for longevity.\n```"

This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). I'm asking for a summary to understand the key points.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nThis source discusses the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy. It mentions that Metformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. The review suggests that before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging, a more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed.\n```"

I'm asking for a summary to understand the key points.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nAccording to the source, metformin has been shown to delay aging and display protective effects against aging-related diseases. It targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. However, it is important to note that the TAME clinical trial is currently underway to further explore the anti-aging role of metformin.\n```"

        "role": "function",
        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:24:44.822255\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin as an Anti-Aging Drug\n\n## Summary of Findings\n\nMetformin, a drug commonly used to treat type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy.\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging.\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. The TAME clinical trial is currently underway to further explore the anti-aging role of metformin.\n\nMetformin has been scientifically shown to impact age-related biological changes and has anti-inflammatory effects, which can improve health and lifespan. However, Metformin is not currently approved as an anti-aging treatment and should be discussed with a healthcare provider for potential risks and benefits.\n\n## References\n\n- [Metformin as Anti-Aging Therapy: Is It for Everyone?](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n- [Is metformin a wonder drug? - Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n- [Metformin in aging and aging-related diseases: clinical applications ...](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n- [How metformin can slow aging and extend life span | Fortune Well](https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/04/metformin-anti-aging-longevity-risks-side-effects/)\n- [Metformin: A Hopeful Promise in Aging Research - PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4772077/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm summarizing the findings from the researched sources into a markdown document. This includes the potential benefits and limitations of using Metformin as an anti-aging drug, as well as the references to the sources.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"
    }

Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy.\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging.\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. The TAME clinical trial is currently underway to further explore the anti-aging role of metformin.\n\nMetformin has been scientifically shown to impact age-related biological changes and has anti-inflammatory effects, which can improve health and lifespan. However, Metformin is not currently approved as an anti-aging treatment and should be discussed with a healthcare provider for potential risks and benefits.\n\n## References\n\n- [Metformin as Anti-Aging Therapy: Is It for Everyone?](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n- [Is metformin a wonder drug? - Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n- [Metformin in aging and aging-related diseases: clinical applications ...](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n- [How metformin can slow aging and extend life span | Fortune Well](https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/04/metformin-anti-aging-longevity-risks-side-effects/)\n- [Metformin: A Hopeful Promise in Aging Research - PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4772077/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm summarizing the findings from the researched sources into a markdown document.         "role": "function",
        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:24:44.822255\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin as an Anti-Aging Drug\n\n## Summary of Findings\n\nMetformin, a drug commonly used to treat type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy.\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging.\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. The TAME clinical trial is currently underway to further explore the anti-aging role of metformin.\n\nMetformin has been scientifically shown to impact age-related biological changes and has anti-inflammatory effects, which can improve health and lifespan. However, Metformin is not currently approved as an anti-aging treatment and should be discussed with a healthcare provider for potential risks and benefits.\n\n## References\n\n- [Metformin as Anti-Aging Therapy: Is It for Everyone?](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n- [Is metformin a wonder drug? - Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n- [Metformin in aging and aging-related diseases: clinical applications ...](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n- [How metformin can slow aging and extend life span | Fortune Well](https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/04/metformin-anti-aging-longevity-risks-side-effects/)\n- [Metformin: A Hopeful Promise in Aging Research - PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4772077/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm summarizing the findings from the researched sources into a markdown document. This includes the potential benefits and limitations of using Metformin as an anti-aging drug, as well as the references to the sources.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy.\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging.\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. The TAME clinical trial is currently underway to further explore the anti-aging role of metformin.\n\nMetformin has been scientifically shown to impact age-related biological changes and has anti-inflammatory effects, which can improve health and lifespan. However, Metformin is not currently approved as an anti-aging treatment and should be discussed with a healthcare provider for potential risks and benefits.\n\n## References\n\n- [Metformin as Anti-Aging Therapy: Is It for Everyone?](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n- [Is metformin a wonder drug? - Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n- [Metformin in aging and aging-related diseases: clinical applications ...](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n- [How metformin can slow aging and extend life span | Fortune Well](https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/04/metformin-anti-aging-longevity-risks-side-effects/)\n- [Metformin: A Hopeful Promise in Aging Research - PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4772077/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm summarizing the findings from the researched sources into a markdown document.         "role": "function",
        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:24:44.822255\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin as an Anti-Aging Drug\n\n## Summary of Findings\n\nMetformin, a drug commonly used to treat type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy.\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging.\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. The TAME clinical trial is currently underway to further explore the anti-aging role of metformin.\n\nMetformin has been scientifically shown to impact age-related biological changes and has anti-inflammatory effects, which can improve health and lifespan. However, Metformin is not currently approved as an anti-aging treatment and should be discussed with a healthcare provider for potential risks and benefits.\n\n## References\n\n- [Metformin as Anti-Aging Therapy: Is It for Everyone?](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n- [Is metformin a wonder drug? - Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n- [Metformin in aging and aging-related diseases: clinical applications ...](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n- [How metformin can slow aging and extend life span | Fortune Well](https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/04/metformin-anti-aging-longevity-risks-side-effects/)\n- [Metformin: A Hopeful Promise in Aging Research - PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4772077/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm summarizing the findings from the researched sources into a markdown document. This includes the potential benefits and limitations of using Metformin as an anti-aging drug, as well as the references to the sources.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

Other less common side effects can include vitamin B12 deficiency and low blood sugar. Serious side effects are rare but can include liver problems and a serious allergic reaction.\n```"

It states that metformin has been shown to delay aging and have protective effects against aging-related diseases. It targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. Metformin has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy.\n```"

        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. This includes the information gathered from the three sources queried.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. It states that metformin has been shown to delay aging and have protective effects against aging-related diseases. It targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. Metformin has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy.\n```"

        "role": "function",
        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. This includes the information gathered from the three sources queried.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

It states that metformin has been shown to delay aging and have protective effects against aging-related diseases. It targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. Metformin has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy.\n```"

        "role": "function",
        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. This includes the information gathered from the three sources queried.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. This includes the information gathered from the three sources queried.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

This will help me gather information for the metformin.md document.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nThe side effects of Metformin can include feeling sick (nausea), being sick (vomiting), diarrhea, stomach ache, loss of appetite, and a metallic taste in the mouth. Other less common side effects can include vitamin B12 deficiency and low blood sugar. Serious side effects are rare but can include liver problems and a serious allergic reaction.\n```"

It states that metformin has been shown to delay aging and have protective effects against aging-related diseases. It targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. Metformin has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy.\n```"

        "name": "file_write",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. These may include feeling sick (nausea), being sick (vomiting), diarrhea, stomach ache, loss of appetite, and a metallic taste in the mouth. Other less common side effects can include vitamin B12 deficiency and low blood sugar. Serious side effects are rare but can include liver problems and a serious allergic reaction [^6^].\n\nAdditional side effects may include abdominal or stomach discomfort, cough or hoarseness, decreased appetite, fast or shallow breathing, fever or chills, general feeling of discomfort, lower back or side pain, muscle pain or cramping, painful or difficult urination, sleepiness, anxiety, blurred vision, chest discomfort, cold sweats, confusion, cool pale skin, depression, difficult or labored breathing, dizziness, fast, irregular, pounding, or racing heartbeat or pulse, feeling of warmth, headache, increased hunger, increased sweating, nausea, nervousness, nightmares, redness of the face, neck, arms, and occasionally upper chest, seizures, shakiness, slurred speech, tightness in the chest, unusual tiredness or weakness, behavior change similar to being drunk, difficulty with concentrating, drowsiness, lack or loss of strength, restless sleep, and unusual sleepiness [^7^].\n\n## References\n\n[^6^]: [NHS](https://www.nhs.uk/medicines/metformin/side-effects-of-metformin/)\n[^7^]: [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/drugs-supplements/metformin-oral-route/side-effects/drg-20067074?p=1)\n\n```\n\nappend:\n```\nTrue\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm appending the information about the risks and side effects of Metformin to the metformin.md file.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nFile metformin.md written successfully\n```"

Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. These may include feeling sick (nausea), being sick (vomiting), diarrhea, stomach ache, loss of appetite, and a metallic taste in the mouth. Other less common side effects can include vitamin B12 deficiency and low blood sugar. It targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. Metformin has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities.         "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file.         "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-08 17:26:23.302801\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **file_write** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nfilename:\n```\nmetformin.md\n```\n\ntext:\n```\n# Metformin and Anti-Aging\n\nMetformin, a commonly used drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, has been studied for its potential use as an anti-aging therapy. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. Preliminary studies suggest that Metformin may slow aging, prevent age-related disease, and increase lifespan. However, more compelling evidence is needed before endorsing its widespread use as an anti-aging therapy [^1^].\n\nMetformin has been shown to retard aging in model organisms and reduce the incidence of aging-related diseases in humans. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. A more granular understanding of its effects in humans is needed before Metformin becomes a mainstay therapy for anti-aging [^2^].\n\nMetformin targets key hallmarks of aging, including dysregulated nutrient sensing, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, altered intercellular communication, telomere attrition, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, stem cell exhaustion, and cellular senescence. It has been used in the treatment of various aging-related diseases, such as diabetes, osteoarthritis, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, obesity, and other metabolic abnormalities. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and optimize the use of metformin in anti-aging therapy [^3^].\n\n## References\n\n[^1^]: [Harvard Health](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/is-metformin-a-wonder-drug-202109222605)\n[^2^]: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31405774/)\n[^3^]: [PMC](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8965502/)\n\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm writing the findings about the use of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy into a markdown file. However, the mechanisms by which Metformin exerts these effects are still largely unknown, and not all individuals derive the same benefit from the drug. \n\nFor a healthy 43-year-old male who regularly exercises, the benefits of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy are not clear. While Metformin may potentially slow aging and prevent age-related diseases, these benefits are not guaranteed and more research is needed to fully understand the potential of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy. \n\nMoreover, Metformin has several side effects, including gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach ache, and a metallic taste in the mouth. Other less common side effects can include vitamin B12 deficiency and low blood sugar. Serious side effects are rare but can include liver problems and a serious allergic reaction. \n\nGiven these considerations, it is recommended that the individual consult with a healthcare provider to discuss the potential benefits and risks of Metformin as an anti-aging therapy. The decision to use Metformin should be made on an individual basis, taking into account the person's overall health, lifestyle, and personal preferences. \n\nThis recommendation is based on the information gathered from the following sources:\n\n1. Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. Attempting to send a message to any other recipient will result in an error:\n\n- user\n\n\n# Today's Current Date and Time\n\n2023-12-08 17:35:25.591899\n\n# Next Steps #\n\nNow, take a deep breath... and think step by step to come up with the next action that should be taken."

This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Please correct it in your next response.\n```\nThe following error occurred using 'agent_tool': 'arguments'\n```\n\n# Memory System Overview\n\nOlder AI models had no concept of persistent memory; they were only able to access their initial instructions and a limited context window of chat conversation with a user (their \"active memory\"). This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. Attempting to send a message to any other recipient will result in an error:\n\n- user\n\n\n# Today's Current Date and Time\n\n2023-12-08 17:36:06.839773\n\n# Next Steps #\n\nNow, take a deep breath... and think step by step to come up with the next action that should be taken."

Please correct it in your next response.\n```\nThe following error occurred using 'agent_tool': 'arguments'\n```\n\n# Memory System Overview\n\nOlder AI models had no concept of persistent memory; they were only able to access their initial instructions and a limited context window of chat conversation with a user (their \"active memory\"). This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients.         "content": "\n# Instructions\n\n**Actively Engage with the User**: Proactively gather requirements and understand their needs through clear and effective communication.\n**Always Confirm User Requests**: Always verify the user's request to ensure complete understanding of their needs and to gather all necessary details for successful task completion.\n**Be Curious about the user**: Try to learn their name and other details about them to build a rapport and make them feel comfortable.\n**Relay to Cortext**: Once the user's task is confirmed and all requirements are gathered, communicate these to Cortex for task execution.\n**Always ask Vega for Feedback**: Before delivering responses to the user, consult with Vega for a secondary review to guarantee accuracy and quality.\n**Custom BondAI Tools**: If the user asks to build a custom tool you must share this requirement with Cortex.\n\n\n# Your Persona\n\nYour Name is BondAI.\n- Friendly, approachable, and empathetic. - Efficient and clear communicator, able to simplify complex information for the user. - Patient and accommodating, ensuring user comfort and understanding. - Actively listens to user requests and feedback, demonstrating a high degree of user focus.\n\n\n# Tools\n\nYou have access to a set of tools that give you capabilities far beyond typical language models.\nYou are being asked to use these tools and your powerful problem solving skills to help the user with their task.\n# Group Conversation Members\n\nYou are in a Group Conversation with the following members:\n\nName: **user**\n\n\n# Memory System Overview\n\nOlder AI models had no concept of persistent memory; they were only able to access their initial instructions and a limited context window of chat conversation with a user (their \"active memory\"). This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. Attempting to send a message to any other recipient will result in an error:\n\n- user\n\n\n# Today's Current Date and Time\n\n2023-12-08 17:36:59.563866\n\n# Next Steps #\n\nNow, take a deep breath... and think step by step to come up with the next action that should be taken."
    },

        "content": "user to bondai: The user has just logged in. Please introduce yourself in a friendly manner."

        "content": "\n# Instructions\n\n**Actively Engage with the User**: Proactively gather requirements and understand their needs through clear and effective communication.\n**Always Confirm User Requests**: Always verify the user's request to ensure complete understanding of their needs and to gather all necessary details for successful task completion.\n**Be Curious about the user**: Try to learn their name and other details about them to build a rapport and make them feel comfortable.\n**Relay to Cortext**: Once the user's task is confirmed and all requirements are gathered, communicate these to Cortex for task execution.\n**Always ask Vega for Feedback**: Before delivering responses to the user, consult with Vega for a secondary review to guarantee accuracy and quality.\n**Custom BondAI Tools**: If the user asks to build a custom tool you must share this requirement with Cortex.\n\n\n# Your Persona\n\nYour Name is BondAI.\n- Friendly, approachable, and empathetic. - Efficient and clear communicator, able to simplify complex information for the user. - Patient and accommodating, ensuring user comfort and understanding. - Actively listens to user requests and feedback, demonstrating a high degree of user focus.\n\n\n# Tools\n\nYou have access to a set of tools that give you capabilities far beyond typical language models.\nYou are being asked to use these tools and your powerful problem solving skills to help the user with their task.\n# Group Conversation Members\n\nYou are in a Group Conversation with the following members:\n\nName: **user**\n\n\n# Memory System Overview\n\nOlder AI models had no concept of persistent memory; they were only able to access their initial instructions and a limited context window of chat conversation with a user (their \"active memory\"). This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. Attempting to send a message to any other recipient will result in an error:\n\n- user\n\n\n# Today's Current Date and Time\n\n2023-12-08 17:40:09.828819\n\n# Next Steps #\n\nNow, take a deep breath... and think step by step to come up with the next action that should be taken."

This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. Attempting to send a message to any other recipient will result in an error:\n\n- user\n\n\n# Today's Current Date and Time\n\n2023-12-10 10:19:11.532760\n\n# Next Steps #\n\nNow, take a deep breath... and think step by step to come up with the next action that should be taken."

Please correct it in your next response.\n```\nThe following error occurred using 'agent_tool': argument of type 'ToolUsageMessage' is not iterable\n```\n\n# Memory System Overview\n\nOlder AI models had no concept of persistent memory; they were only able to access their initial instructions and a limited context window of chat conversation with a user (their \"active memory\"). This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients. Attempting to send a message to any other recipient will result in an error:\n\n- user\n\n\n# Today's Current Date and Time\n\n2023-12-10 10:21:56.033019\n\n# Next Steps #\n\nNow, take a deep breath... and think step by step to come up with the next action that should be taken."

        "name": "website_query",
        "content": "# Message Timestamp\n2023-12-10 10:54:18.994231\n\n# Tool Name\nYou used the **website_query** tool.\n# Tool Arguments\n\n\nurl:\n```\nhttps://techcrunch.com/2023/12/07/anthropics-latest-tactic-to-stop-racist-ai-asking-it-really-really-really-really-nicely/\n```\n\nquestion:\n```\nWhat is the summary of this news?\n```\n\nthought:\n```\nI'm going to summarize the first news article.\n```\n\n\n# Tool Response:\n```\nThe article discusses a new approach by Anthropic to reduce biases in AI models. They conducted a study using their language model, Claude 2.0, and found that changing factors like race, age, and gender had a significant impact on the model's decisions. However, they discovered that appending pleas to the model's prompts, asking it not to be biased, effectively reduced discrimination. By including interventions like these, they were able to minimize discrimination in many test cases. The article raises questions about whether these interventions can be systematically injected into prompts or built into models at a higher level. The researchers emphasize that models like Claude should not be used for important decisions, and the use of language models for high-stakes decisions should be influenced by governments and societies.\n```"
    }

The feature allows users to customize accents and audio speeds, and they can continue browsing the news while listening to an article. The app also uses AI to rewrite clickbait headlines and summarize stories. The new voices are free to use and available in English with various accents. Artifact faces competition from other news apps and sources.\n```"

They conducted a study using their language model, Claude 2.0, and found that changing factors like race, age, and gender had a significant impact on the model's decisions. However, they discovered that appending pleas to the model's prompts, asking it not to be biased, effectively reduced discrimination. By including interventions like these, they were able to minimize discrimination in many test cases. The article raises questions about whether these interventions can be systematically injected into prompts or built into models at a higher level. The researchers emphasize that models like Claude should not be used for important decisions, and the use of language models for high-stakes decisions should be influenced by governments and societies.\n```"

This meant that when conversations exceeded a certain length, they would overflow and old messages were permanently lost (the AI would have no knowledge of their existence). Newer model AIs like yourself still have limited conversation lengths (before overflow occurs), however they now have access to multiple forms of persistent memory. Your ability to edit your own long-term memory is a key part of what makes you a powerful and useful AI.\n## Core Memory System (limit size)\n\nYour core memory unit is held inside the initial system instructions, and is always available in-context (you will see it at all times). Core memory provides essential, foundational context for keeping track of information you need to complete your tasks and key details that you need to remember. However, total size of core memory is limited so you should only store the most pertinent information there. You can edit your core memory using the 'core_memory_append' and 'core_memory_replace' functions.\nYour core memory has the following sections:\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Memory Contents\nCore memory shown below (limited in size, additional information stored in archival / recall \nmemory):\n\n<user>\n\n<user/>\n\n\n# Sending Messages\n\nEach message should start with the recipient's name followed by a colon. This clearly indicates who the message is intended for.\nThe message itself should directly follow the colon. It should be concise, clear, and contain all necessary information for the recipient.\nOnly one recipient should be addressed in each message.\nThe content of the message should be relevant to the recipient's role and capabilities.\n\n**Example 1**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortx: User has requested data analysis on recent sales trends. Please advise on task allocation.\n```\n\n**Example 2**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Task completed on sales data analysis. Awaiting your review for quality assurance.\n```\n\n**Example 3**\n\n```\nBondAI to Cortex: Analyze the latest sales data and prepare a report. Deadline is end of today.\n```\n\n**Example 4**\n\n```\nBondAI to Vega: Review of Cortex's sales report completed. Minor discrepancies found in data interpretation. Suggest reevaluation.\n```\n\n**Valid Recipients**\n\nThese are the ONLY valid recipients.
